intro: Browallia plazapampae, commonly known as the Plazapampa browallia, is a flowering plant native to the Andean region of South America. It belongs to the Solanaceae family, which includes tomatoes and potatoes, and is characterized by its showy, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky soils at high altitudes, showcasing adaptations to its harsh environment. Its foliage is covered in fine hairs, which help reduce water loss in arid conditions. The flowers are pollinated primarily by hummingbirds, making it an important species in local ecosystems.
